name: DEFCON
description: Inspired by the 1983 cult classic film, Wargames, DEFCON superbly evokes the tension, paranoia and suspicion of the Cold War era, playing on the fascinating aspects of psychological gameplay that occur during strategic nuclear warfare. You play a General hidden deep within an underground bunker.
minimum_requirements: Recommended: Windows XP, P3-600-Geforce 2, 128 Mb RAM, 60 Mb Hard Disk, Internet connection for multiplayer games

One of those games that is both well programmed and well made to make nuclear war just another giddy joyride. The game focuses on a world during the late 70's and early 80's, where nuclear war is taking place, and up to 6 nations can declare into it, the nations include The European union (and several other nations not currently in the EU) The USSR, (A and some parts of Kazakhstan) Asia (Not Ocenia, Australia, or Mongolia) Lain America (Not including Cuba) Africa, and North America including Canada and the United States. In order to win, you must get more points than your foes, you get points by killing each millions of people with your ICBMs, there are multiple modes, but I'm covering the stock mode. The game starts at Defcon 5, you can place Radar on your territory, Nuclear Silos (Which will shoot down enemy bombers and fighters as well as launch ICBM) and finally, military air bases that can launch Bombers with nuclear capacity, and fighters. Also during Defcon 5, you can place ships, either battleships, which focus on fighting directly at sea, Subs, which can scan the area and launch nuclear missiles (However said launch will let the rest of the players see them) and Carries, that can't fight, but can use depth charges to take out said Subs, and can also launch bombers and fighter jets. (Each jet also has some small amount of radar to let you see enemy silos and Radar) You can only place units until Defcon 3, when battle becomes more intense, and you are allowed to send jets into enemy territory to scan for military bases and whatnot. After getting to Defcon 1, Nuclear weapons are permitted, and can be launched by Bomber, Silo (Which will prevent the Silo from protecting against incoming jet, bomber, or ICBM.) After you or them launch, the entire game flashes with the warning that one of the players dared to go launch nuclear missiles, and silos (Or Subs) That are launching them will be revealed to the world, and nuclear missiles will launch, but will only be seen if it's under a general radar of a team.. A nuclear missile will destroy Radar in one hit, and air bases in two, and silos in three, also destroying half of that building's current housed warfare. (Be it be bombers/fighters or ICBMs) A missile, hitting a city, will kill half it's living population, which is usually a a couple million each hit, depending on where you strike.  Despite a majority of the community is gone, the game is still here, unlike TF2, which is aimed at multiplayer play, this can be played with well programmed AI, of which aren't generic, and actually are quite hard at times. The achieves, however, can't actually be attained form fighting bots, so you have to play online to actually get them, but due to a dwindling community, it's quite hard to find those players, so try to get friends to play if you want to competition against an actual person.

This game is scarier than any of the horror games I've played- and it's not even a horror game!   It's a simulation/strategy game about nuclear war, if you couldn't figure that out. You nuke the enemies' cities to earn a better score, and if the enemy nukes your cities (or destroys your units), then you lose points and stuff. The team with the highest score wins. It is a very dark game, for example: you can hear people crying sometimes and when a city is hit with a nuclear missile it shows the amount of people who were killed, it's especially frightening if it's a place you live in or if loved ones live there. The soundtrack is FANTASTIC, and sets the mood of the game PERFECTLY. I'm not very good at playing the game, but you don't even have to play! You can set up AI battles, and I sometimes hop on and watch one. They're actually pretty entertaining, and the AI is good in my book. Speaking of setting things up, it's very customizable. A single game can be very time consuming if played in real-time, and the nukes take a while to reach its target. Also, when I played in real-time (and quit after ten minutes i dont have time for that) I felt like I was the one giving the OK to launch the nukes and responsible for the millions of deaths I caused, not to mention feeling guilty about my cities getting exploded by the enemies. Overall, it's a pretty good game, but it can be difficult and is very dark. Unfortunately, the last update was sometime in 2014, so it seems that the developers have stopped updating it, however it feels finished and the price is reasonable for $9.99 USD.    8/10  - Solid game.   But why is it scarier than the horror games I've played? That's because it can actually happen...

I want to recommend this game on the sheer philosophical level that games are an art form to be experienced.  This game made me feel things. As gamers we've slain zombies, killed Nazi's and even exploded innocent towns in fallout. And yet, through all the years of gore and hyperviolence this simple vectorized representation of the world has made me feel more guilt than any video game I've played. This game is unsettling to it's core and has made a huge impact on me.  The soundtrack is, in my opinion, perfection and lends a staggering amount of gravitas and torment to the game. Even when you're winning, it is disturbing to think you so easily caused 5.8 million deaths in Tokyo. In the background you hear the final gasping cough of a women as she succumbs to radiation poisoning or the cry of a mother over the death of her newborn.  Even if unintended, this game makes a moving and bold statement, all represented by a very detached and matter-of-fact way.  At least try the demo!

DEFCON is an incredibly depressing, boring, bland, poorly designed, cheeky, insulting parody of real-time strategy games whose primary gameplay focuses on not having any care whatsoever for what happens during a round (read: the polar opposite of what you usually do when playing any game ever.)  Due to its extreme callousness and its abhorrent, hamfisted gameplay, DEFCON is among a small collection of software calling itself a game that actually makes me angry every second that I am playing it (the only other I can name right now is The Stanley Parable.) That is because I cannot accept that someone was actually callous and asinine enough to put untold effort into this piece of ♥♥♥♥ and put it out with their tongues firmly in their cheeks, or that there are people in the world who actually enjoy watching this game.  Note I didn't say playing this game, because that isn't really a thing you do.  Each player is assigned a general region of the world in which they may place a bunch of ♥♥♥♥ they should not condone any attachment or value to. It seems to be that the only attacks you have are battleships, submarines, silos, and aircraft, the last of which are launched from carriers and airports.  The game will begin in DEFCON 5 and eventually progress to DEFCON 1.  DEFCON 5: (Placement phase) No hostile actions are permitted; enemy units are completely invisible DEFCON 4: (Placement phase) Enemy units become visible to Radars / ships / planes DEFCON 3: Ships and planes may now attack DEFCON 2: APPARENTLY ♥♥♥♥ING POINTLESS AS NOTHING CHANGES DEFCON 1: Nukes may be launched (silos, subs) DEFCON 0: Basically if DEFCON 1 goes on for too long the war ends automatically and whoever's the least dead wins.  You will quickly find that the game WILL NOT ♥♥♥♥ING LET YOU PLACE UNITS except under incredibly specific criteria. That is, you have to click-hunt until you find a spot you can actually put something. This is most obvious when placing seacraft, because they have to be within your territory but also in fairly deep water, which is probably like 5% of your ♥♥♥♥ing territory.  The biggest problem with this game is that it is little more than a long-exposure camera simulator. You are playing on a ♥♥♥♥♥♥, nigh-unintelligible projection map based on some classic movie because creators who aren't able to make their own iconic content just poorly mooch off of someone else's already popular work (see Chris-chan, Borderlands 2's writing, etc.) You will give a few orders and then sit there and wait while their trails sloooowly fill the screen as they go do whatever the ♥♥♥♥ they're doing why do I even care in a game that tells me flat-out that nobody's going to win.  The projection map has a small problem called 'you can't see jack ♥♥♥♥'. This can be abated by toggling on or off the KIND OF IMPORTANT WHETHER THEY ARE ON OR OFF OVERLAYS that do such things as show you your radar range and where everyone's territory is, as this can affect how much the unit icons blend in with the background by shoving highlights and ♥♥♥♥ everywhere.  I wish I could write more but I cannot stand playing this hunk of YOLO crap long enough to obtain further information on it.  I honestly can't tell who this game is supposed to be marketed to. It's completely uninteresting and underwhelming in every possible way, and its message is an explicit mockery of human suffering.  Don't play this if you have any respect for games or humanity at all. It's filthy.

'We forge futures out of pain and grief, Commander. The computers and the communications officers and the EV As and the displays only serve to isolate us so we can be inhuman. We're monsters, son. Cold, mechanical, rational monsters, and the only way we win is by being colder, more mechanical, and more rational than the next monster moving his little pieces on the screen.... You point, you click, and they die. It's how it works.' — Colonel Nick Parker, Tiberium Wars 'Chapter XVIII'   Defcon is a simple looking yet complex game of strategy. From the beginning you must place resources and units around the map to determine your defense game. Cluster resources or spread them out? Defend heavily populated cities first or risk losing protection for more coverage? Deploy fleets in the Atlantic or the Pacific? Each defending each area has its own unique challenges to overcome which can make for a huge amount of strategies and layouts that anybody can test.   Beyond the gameplay is the atmosphere. The very basic graphics evoke the feeling of being in a war room straight out of the movie WarGames and the slow sad music, ambient sounds of orders slowly and carefully given through the room, a weeping woman in the corner, the sound of The Lords Prayer softly played over the loudspeaker, and the low hum whenever a nuke explodes makes you feel the sheer magnitude of everything you are witnessing. You are watching the world die and YOU are making it happen. Seeing a town you grew up in disappear in a flash of light and reading the tally of the dead is downright soul-crushing.   Over all this is a very experiential and fun game for LAN parties. The only problem is that online matchmaking takes forever because of a small community. Otherwise this game is very strategic, very fun, and hauntingly beautiful.

Inspired by the movie 'Wargames', got this game for a few bucks and well worth that much.  Simple vector graphics. Simple game mechanics. Nice ambient music. Community modding on the Introversion developer's website.  It could very well be the game of 'Global Thermonuclear War' that Matthew Broderick was playing in the movie. Or the NORAD command center. Who knows, maybe it IS the command center that your multiplayer game got linked to by mistake ;-)

An odd game that manages to provide quick, easy matches or long and drawn out conflicts in one system. Either play with bots or humans, play diplomatically or ruthlessly, bide your time and strike within seconds of Defcon 1. Any way you play, just remember that in the end; no one wins, everybody just dies.
If you love strategy games, than you should buy this game! 10/10
